channel.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
channel.description:
This is the basic look of Ubuntu. I changed the theme but you can have the default theme it's just as cool.
I don't recommend Ubuntu for major gaming. It's very fast for other things though.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bMF1Ag35nHc
If you want to download Ubuntu, you can download it at www.Ubuntu.com or you can look up a tutorial on how to dual boot it with windows.
What do you guys think of Linux?

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

i.e. gimp has most of the major features photoshop has, except photoshop does the job better and makes getting the job done easier.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I’ve never even heard of CMYK. As I said, the height of my graphical editing ability is cropping pictures and making backgrounds transparent. Resize, rotating and the like I do on the command-line with imagemagick. So GIMP is excellent for everything I need it for.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

The GIMP has CMYK support now, it’s not as good as Photoshops but headway is being made.

I assume you don’t use CMYK and just heard someone else talk about it since you fudged the acronym.

I would pretty much agree with Unhandled on this I think… “it’s pretty much as capable as Photoshop, but it’s not Photoshop”. Major hardcore graphics people would probably disagree, but whatever. I prefer Photoshop, any day of the week. That doesn’t help if I want to run Linux and not pay a million dollars to edit photos, though.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:55, topic:304514”][quote author=mwiebelhaus link=topic=400781.msg3361427#msg3361427 date=1286409945]
Your right I did. I don’t agree with your first sentence. Then the rest I agree with.
[/quote]

I’d like a concrete example of something common that photoshop can do and gimp can’t. I don’t really use either, every once in a blue moon I have to make an image have a transparent background or something and of course I use gimp.[/quote]

Its just alot of little things, they hit many of the major features but GIMP just doesn’t have the ease of use and feel of photoshop. I dont like having a seperate menu bar for each picture, and the way you have to get to the tool you want or apply a certain affect just takes longer to get to, oh yeah and CYMK.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:52, topic:304514”][quote author=Unhandled link=topic=400781.msg2971803#msg2971803 date=1254004746]
As a user of both Photoshop and Gimp, I’d say Gimp is just as capable as Photoshop. The problem is, it’s not Photoshop. Adobe has done a superb job in terms of user experience and workflow. In my opinion, Gimp is incredibly awkward to use compared to Photoshop, and I just don’t see myself being nearly as efficient even if I did use it every day.
[/quote]

Mainly a response to Mopman: I have used gimp and hate it. The placement of controls along with other things along with the huge amount of missing features GIMP is not a good alternative to Photoshop unless you are just doing basic adjustments. But I agree with what Unhandled says.[/quote]
You just contradicted yourself idiet.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Unhandled:

As a user of both Photoshop and Gimp, I’d say Gimp is just as capable as Photoshop. The problem is, it’s not Photoshop. Adobe has done a superb job in terms of user experience and workflow. In my opinion, Gimp is incredibly awkward to use compared to Photoshop, and I just don’t see myself being nearly as efficient even if I did use it every day.

Mainly a response to Mopman: I have used gimp and hate it. The placement of controls along with other things along with the huge amount of missing features GIMP is not a good alternative to Photoshop unless you are just doing basic adjustments. But I agree with what Unhandled says.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Wizzup?:

Cygwin is cool, and you can try http://www.colinux.org/

Yes, on the rare occasion when I’m in windows I have to have Cygwin installed, for ssh if for nothing else.

Anyhow, never seen that colinux thing, and all I can say is ‘weird’.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @KO9 KO9
item.description:
@KO9 wrote:

Heh, I know this thread is quite old now but I kind of forgot about it ;p.

Has/does anyone use(d) http://www.cygwin.com/ ?

Cygwin is a Linux-like environment for Windows. It consists of two parts: # A DLL (cygwin1.dll) which acts as a Linux API emulation layer providing substantial Linux API functionality. # A collection of tools which provide Linux look and feel.

I’ve used it a few times, mainly for the bash shell that you get (:.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

there’s a lot of stuff like that “andlinux”, seems pointless when you can indeed just run a vm, which is about the same, only more stable…

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“cooper, post:43, topic:304514”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=400781.msg3073568#msg3073568 date=1261677079]

I believe we have the equivalent of Wine on Windows.

A program that can run Linux program on windows? Link me.
[/quote]
http://www.andlinux.org/
Apparently this allows you to run linux applications within windows.[/quote]

Pretty much what Unhandled said above. If this application is used for running linux programs under windows, then
http://www.virtualbox.org/
Can be used to run windows programs flawlessly inside of linux.
Come to think of it it can also be used to run linux inside of windows too.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

inertia:

But it does what it’s supposed to do?

Sort of. It’s more running Linux applications inside of Linux inside of Windows. I could say Linux is great for running windows apps then as long as you use a VM.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:44, topic:304514”][quote author=cooper link=topic=400781.msg3088434#msg3088434 date=1262682917]

I believe we have the equivalent of Wine on Windows.

A program that can run Linux program on windows? Link me.

http://www.andlinux.org/
Apparently this allows you to run linux applications within windows.
[/quote]
The thing is, that’s just Linux running inside windows, and because Linux is free/opensource it’s relatively easy to do. With WINE however, they have to reimplement the entire windows API from scratch.[/quote]
But it does what it’s supposed to do?

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“cooper, post:43, topic:304514”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=400781.msg3073568#msg3073568 date=1261677079]

I believe we have the equivalent of Wine on Windows.

A program that can run Linux program on windows? Link me.
[/quote]
http://www.andlinux.org/
Apparently this allows you to run linux applications within windows.[/quote]
The thing is, that’s just Linux running inside windows, and because Linux is free/opensource it’s relatively easy to do. With WINE however, they have to reimplement the entire windows API from scratch.

Read full topic

[/quote]

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

it doesnt require you to use a password, but it does require you to escalate your privileges in short bursts, so that essentially your account is a non-admin account except when you say its an admin account

… just like running sudo with the group wheel able to use no password, like many distros do

what extra benefit does the password offer, except from stopping people sitting at the machine escalating (which isnt the point of this type of protection anyway, imo)

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu - Most popular Linux Distro
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:40, topic:304514”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=400781.msg3078974#msg3078974 date=1262033803]

It’s more equivalent to ubuntus default user imo, due to uac

Ubuntu, by default, requires you have a (strong) password for your default account, and won’t let you log in with the root account at all.
[/quote]

exactly, it gives you a limited account with the ability to sudo - just like windows vista/7 :/[/quote]

Windows 7/vista does not do that however. It does not require that you have a password at all, and it starts you off with an Administrator account. I just installed 7 a few days ago and this is the case.

Read full topic
